Dictionary.Name: The Free On-line Dictionary of Computing (27 SEP 03)

Definition.WordDefinition:
Sequel
1. Precursor to SQL.
["System R: Relational Approach to Database Management", IBM Res Lab, San Jose, reprinted in Readings in Database Systems].
2. U Leeds. Theorem prover specification language. Pattern matching notation similar to Prolog. Compiled into Lisp.
[Proc ICJAI 13].
{(ftp://agora.leeds.ac.uk/scs/logic/)}.

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Sequel \Se"quel\ (s[=e]"kw[e^]l), n. [L. sequela, fr. sequit to follow: cf. F. s['e]quelle a following. See {Sue} to follow.] 1. That which follows; a succeeding part; continuation; as, the sequel of a man's advantures or history. [1913 Webster]
O, let me say no more! Gather the sequel by that went before. --Shak. [1913 Webster]
2. Consequence; event; effect; result; as, let the sun cease, fail, or swerve, and the sequel would be ruin. [1913 Webster]
3. Conclusion; inference. [R.] --Whitgift. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: Virtual Entity of Relevant Acronyms (Version 1.9, June 2002)

Definition.WordDefinition: SEQUEL Structured English QUEry Language (IBM, DB, SQL, predecessor)
sequel n 1: something that follows something else [syn: {subsequence}] 2: a part added to a book or play that continues and extends it [syn: {continuation}]
